_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CATLETTSBURG REFINING, LLC
Risk Management Program Plan


1.  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for its employees, the public, and the environment.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC's policy is to conduct activities so as to protect and promote the health and safety of its employees, customers, and others who may be affected by these activities, and to limit adverse effects on the physical environment in which its activities are carried out.  As part of this policy, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has established systems to help ensure safe operation of the processes at this facility.  One part of these systems is a Risk Management Program (RMP) that helps manage the risks at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC and that complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) rule 40 CFR part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs (the RMP rule). One of the requirements of the RMP rule is to submit a risk management plan (RMPlan) describing the Risk Management Program at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC.  This document is intended to satisfy the RMPlan executive summary requirements of the RMP rule and to provide the public with a description of the risk management program at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC.

1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC is committed to the safety of its employees and the public, and to the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances.  Key to this commitment is the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances in and around the refinery.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC utilizes engineering controls, inspection programs, and detailed procedures as a means to prevent accidental releases.  In the event of a release, the refinery has a well trained emergency response team to contain, mitigate, monitor, and stop the release.  The refiner

y has fully staffed and trained emergency response teams for fire fighting (Fire and Rescue Squad), medical emergencies, and for ambient air monitoring (Air Monitoring Team).  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC evaluates each situation, responds based on the particular circumstances, and if necessary, requests assistance from outside emergency responders, including local fire departments, in controlling and containing the release and to prevent and/or reduce the consequences of the release.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC, the local emergency planning committees (LEPCs), and the fire department have also established a system for warning the community if an accident occurs that could threaten the community.

The Catlettsburg Refining, LLC Manager has overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the risk management program at the facility.  However, the specific responsibilities for certain aspects of that program have been delegated by the Manager to other personnel who report either directly, or through other management personnel, to the Manager.  Those relationships are depicted on the facility organization chart.  Specific responsibility for the implementation of the Process Safety Management (PSM) and accident prevention program has been delegated to the Safety and PSM Manager.  Similarly, responsibility for the RMP hazard assessment and risk management plan has been delegated to the Environmental Manager.  The facility emergency response program, including compliance with the RMP aspects of that effort, is also the responsibility of the Environmental Manager.  In keeping with our policy that safe operation is part of everyone's job, many other refinery personnel are also involved in RMP activities on an ongoing basis.

1.2  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC Regulated Substances

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC is a full range refinery and petroleum products facility located in Catlettsburg, Kentucky.  We use crude oil as our feed material and make a variety of petro

leum-based products, including gasoline, diesel fuel, kerosene, asphalt, lube stocks, specialty chemicals, and liquefied petroleum gases such as propane and butane.  Many of these products are flammable substances that EPA has specifically listed in the RMP rule and are present in our process units above the EPA threshold quantity of 10,000 lb.  In total, we have 38 process units that are covered by the RMP rule because of their flammable process materials.  These units are listed in the RMP data included with this summary.
 
Catlettsburg Refining, LLC also handles 1 toxic substance, hydrofluoric acid (HF), in sufficient quantity to be covered by the RMP rule.  The alkylation unit uses HF to make high quality gasoline components.
        
1.3  Offsite Consequence Analysis

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC performed an offsite consequence analysis to estimate the potential for an accidental release of a regulated substance that could affect the public or the environment.  The offsite consequence analysis consists of evaluating both worst-case scenarios and alternative release scenarios.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC does not expect a worst-case release scenario to ever occur.  An alternative release scenario represents a release that might occur during the lifetime of a facility.  Alternative release scenarios can be used to aid the Local Emergency Planning Committees (LEPCs) and Disaster and Emergency Services (DES) in enhancing the community emergency response plan.  We have shared this information with the LEPC & DES and other organizations involved in emergency response activities.  The information is also available to local residents and businesses. 

The paragraphs below briefly describe scenarios which are included in our risk management plan.  Please recognize that none of these events have occurred at our facility. Also we have emergency mitigation systems and well trained emergency response personnel that will reduce the consequences of the events if they occurred. In al

l cases, if such events occurred, we would actuate our emergency response plan to respond to the event, notify local authorities, and take appropriate actions to protect both our employees, people in the community, and the environment.

        Worst-case Release Scenarios

The worst-case scenario associated with toxic substances in RMP-covered processes at the refinery is a failure of the hydrofluoric (HF) acid storage tank in our HF Alkylation Unit during a unit shutdown. If such a failure released the maximum inventory of the tank (160,000 pounds), the HF acid would vaporize, resulting in a toxic exposure hazard in the downwind area that would extend outside the boundary of the refinery. The maximum inventory of HF acid is stored in the HF acid tank only during unit shutdowns, which typically occur for two to three weeks every three years.  As specified by EPA, this analysis assumes that all of the HF acid is released to the air and no credit is taken for operation of our HF acid vapor mitigation system (i.e., a water spray system to reduce the amount of vapor that leaves the unit if released).

The worst-case scenario associated with a release of flammable substances in RMP-covered processes at the refinery is a vapor cloud explosion, involving the failure of the protective dome for the feed lines to the underground propane cavern.  The analysis assumes that the maximum inventory of 5,900,000 pounds is released, completely vaporizes, and ignites, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. Because there are some public receptor locations just outside the refinery property, this event could affect members of the public at those closest locations.

There are no Program 1 processes at the refinery; therefore, no additional worst-case analyses are reported in this risk management plan.  Also, we did not identify any worst-case scenarios that would affect public receptors other than the receptors affected by the scenarios reported above.

        Alternative Release Scenarios

We anal

yzed numerous release scenarios for toxic materials. The single toxic release scenario being reported as part of the risk management plan involves a release of HF acid from a failure of a HF acid tank truck unloading hose.  This would result in a release of 1,200 pounds of HF acid in the time required to isolate the tank truck, thereby stopping the release. Because the unloading process is closely monitored by both Catlettsburg Refining, LLC personnel as well as the tank truck operator, the duration of the event was limited to the time required to activate one of several safety shutoff switches located around the truck. However, the analysis indicated that the resulting HF vapor cloud could result in toxic exposures outside the refinery boundary.

The alternative release scenario in our risk management plan for flammable substances is a vapor cloud explosion from a failure of a bleeder valve in the propane transfer line from the underground cavern to the refinery. The valve failure would release 62,000 pounds of flammable material in the time required to isolate the release. The analysis assumed that all of this material would be involved in a vapor cloud explosion and showed that the resulting overpressure from the explosion would affect public receptor locations outside the refinery.  Since operating personnel are not adjacent to the cavern, the duration of the event was allowed to continue for a period of time to detect and isolate the release.

As stated previously, we have included details regarding these scenarios in the additional information submitted to EPA with this executive summary, and have shared that information with the LEPC and DES, other organizations involved in emergency planning, and members of the local community.  If you are interested in the RMP information, please contact the refinery at (606) 921-2000 and request to speak to our Environmental Manager.

1.4  Accidental Release Prevention Program

The following is a summary of the general acc

ident prevention program in place at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC.  The processes at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC that are regulated by the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  The OSHA PSM requirements are very similar to the EPA RMP requirements for refineries, therefore this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements.  The PSM program at this facility has been extended by Catlettsburg Refining, LLC, where necessary, to satisfy EPA's Program Level 3 accident prevention program requirements.

Employee Participation

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention.  Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) team, incident investigation, and compliance audit teams. Employees have access to all information created as part of Catlettsburg Refining, LLC accident prevention program.  Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in an employee participation plan that is maintained at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC and addresses each accident prevention program element.  In addition, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has a number of initiatives under way that address process safety and employee safety issues.  These initiatives include forming teams such as the Safety Awareness For Everyone (S.A.F.E.) committee to promote both process and personal safety. The teams typically have members from various areas of the plant, including operations, maintenance, engineering, and plant management.

Process Safety Information

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits f

or key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. Specific departments within Catlettsburg Refining, LLC are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information.   These documents can be found in each of the control rooms for the process units and in the Emergency Operations Center (EOC) room.

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs). This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals.  For specific process areas, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, composition) in a Not-To-Exceed Limits Document.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC ensures that the process is maintained within these limits by using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrumentation systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems). 

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has a comprehensive PHA program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify haza

t its work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform Catlettsburg Refining, LLC personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with access to (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, (4) safe work practices, and (5) a work permit process (i.e., for hot work, confined space, etc.) prior to their beginning work.  In addition, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.

Pre-startup Safety Reviews

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC conducts a pre-startup safety review for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the review is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  The review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness.  A review involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

Mechanical Integr

rds and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage those hazards.

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC primarily uses the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform these evaluations.  HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques available.  The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes recommendations for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary. 

The PHA team recommendations are forwarded to local management for resolution. Implementation of safety improvements in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team.  They ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive prompt attention.  All approved safety improvements being implemented in response to PHA team recommendations are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each recommendation is documented and retained.

To help ensure that the controls put in place originally and those added as a result of the HAZOP do not eventually deviate significantly from the original safety intent, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC periodically updates and revalidates the PHA results.  These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating.  Offsite effects have been considered in all PHAs completed after August 1996.  The results and recommendations from these updates are documented and retained.  Once again, the team findings are forwarded to management for consideration, and the final resolution of the recommendations is documented and retained.

Operating Procedures

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC maintains written procedures that addr

ess various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  Procedures are reviewed annually as current and accurate.  Procedures are maintained current by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made to the process.  In addition, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC operating procedures provide guidance on how to respond to events that result in exceeding safe operating limits for specific process or equipment parameters.  The written operating procedures are readily available to operators in each of the control rooms for the process units and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks on a computer based system.

Training

To complement the written procedures for process operations, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has implemented a company training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  New employees receive basic training in Catlettsburg Refining, LLC operations if they are not already familiar with such operations.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks.  After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained.  This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years.  All of this training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.


Contractors

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC uses contractors to supplemen

ity

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.

Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their job in a safe manner.  Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training.  Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels).  If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service, or a management of change team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.

Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs.  This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made. 

Safe Work Practices

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support p

ersonnel, (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation and de-energization of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a hot work permit and procedure to control welding and other spark-producing activities, and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.
Management of Change

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.  Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided with any necessary training on the change.

Incident Investigation

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or process related personnel injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to Catlettsburg Refining, LLC management for resolution. Corr

ective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations. 

Compliance Audits

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC periodically conducts audits to determine if procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years.  Both hourly and management personnel participate during the audit.  The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to Catlettsburg Refining, LLC management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.

1.5  Chemical-specific Prevention Steps

    The processes at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC use chemicals that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. The accident prevention program previously summarized is applied to all  processes at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC. Collectively, these prevention program activities help reduce the likelihood of accidental releases occurring as a result of equipment failures or human errors involving hydrofluoric acid and flammable substances.

    In addition to the accident prevention program activities, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

Release Detection

(    Chemical-spec

ific detectors with alarms in selected areas including HF detectors in the HF Alkylation Unit and H2S monitors in the Sulfur Recovery Units 

* Closed circuit TV monitors in each of the control rooms including the HF Alkylation Unit

* Air Monitoring Team



Release Containment/Control

* Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate process materials to prevent overpressure damage to equipment

* Scrubbers to neutralize chemical releases such as the fuel gas scrubbers to remove hydrogen sulfide 

* Manual and automatic valves to permit isolation of the process

* Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature)

* Deinventory system for HF in the HF Alkylation unit 

* Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases

* Redundant equipment and instrumentation where needed (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, redundant firewater pumps)

* Release mitigation system for the HF Alkylation unit

* Fire suppression and extinguishing systems throughout the refinery (e.g., at the solvent loading rack, propane bullets, the RCC unit)

* Trained emergency response personnel including 40 trained Fire and Rescue Squad members

* Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)

* Several blast-resistant control buildings to help protect shutdown control systems and personnel

1.6  Five-year Accident History

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC maintains a 5-year accident history that fulfills the requirements of the RMP rule. This history indicates a good record of accidental release prevention over the past 5 years.  No releases of regulated substances have occurred from Catlettsburg Refining, LLC within the last 5 years that have resulted in offsite consequences.  There have been some incidents at the facility which resulted in onsite consequences.  We investigate every incident very carefully to determine ways to prevent similar incidents from

occurring. The following table is a summary of the incidents at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC within the past 5 years which resulted in onsite consequences:

1.7  Emergency Response Program

    The Catlettsburg Refining, LLC maintains a written emergency response plan, which is in place to protect employee and public safety as well as the environment. The purpose of the emergency response plan is to minimize the impact on the refinery and surrounding areas in the event of an emergency situation.  The plan consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The plan also addresses severe weather conditions.  The plan address all aspects of emergency response, including responsibilities of the Emergency Response Team, proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, refinery evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after the initiation of the response, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and postincident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  In addition, the Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures to perform their specific emergency response duties. The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to refinery processes or facilities.   

The overall emergency response program for the Catlettsburg Refining, LLC is coordinated with the Boyd County, Kentucky LEPC/DES and Cabell/Wayne County, West Virginia LEPC and with offsite responders who would be called to support emergency response efforts

if required. This coordination includes periodic meetings with the agencies, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  In addition, emergencies at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC are classified in one of three levels as specified by the Emergency Response plan.  Level One emergencies involve minor incidents limited to the work site.  Level Two emergencies involve incidents which will not have an offsite impact but will require the activation of the Incident Command system and the Emergency Response teams.  Level Three emergencies involve incidents which could have an offsite impact and require the Incident Commander to contact the local fire departments (911 centers) and make a recommendation for public action.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC/DES officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  In addition to participating in periodic LEPC/DES meetings, the Catlettsburg Refining, LLC conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC/DES and emergency response organizations, and the refinery provides refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the refinery. 

1.8   Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC continually strives to improve the safety of its operations through periodic safety reviews, the incident investigation program, and a program soliciting safety suggestions from the employees.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications to the process.  The following types of changes are planned during the next 5 years:

* Revisions to personnel training programs.
* Revised written operating procedures in process units.
* Revisions to safe work practices
